Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2013 01:49PM - edited Jul 18, 2013 01:51PM by DiddleyDoo That's strange - well, we have this for now.  I'm happy that things are moving forward for you with your appointments next week.  The great thing about where you are going is that they'll take a team approach to your care, which I think really is the best way to treat such a complicated and serious disease.  They'll also have supportive care through nurses and social workers who can help you with other issues that may pop up during your fight.  The docs won't know the extent of everything until they get the additional imaging and after your surgery.  It sounds like you have all of the information you can at the moment but you'll get a lot more next week! No news yet.  They told me 3-5 business days, so I'll be patient.  It's only been two days ... maybe tomorrow...
Posts.Title: Confused - How is Metastatic disease diagnosed? del3 DiddleyDoo

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2013 07:06AM DiddleyDoo wrote: Before the scan you will drink a solution that has a radioactive tracer in it.  The tracer is essentially a molecule that is structurally similar to glucose, which is a sugar that our cells require to make energy and perform its specific functions.  Cells that are using a lot of glucose will take up more of the radio-labeled glucose analogue and this label will light up on the PET scan.  We do have cells that normally use a lot of glucose, however, rapidly dividing/proliferating cells can be identified by a radiologist, who will analyze your results.  This is a good test because it can help to identify early mets that may not have grown yet to a size that can be detected by less sensitive scans.  Best wishes to you - I hope that you have a very boring looking (normal!) scan!
Posts.Title: Confused - How is Metastatic disease diagnosed? del3 DiddleyDoo

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2013 12:36PM DiddleyDoo wrote: Hi Deb - I saw your message and sent you a private message.  I don't know why you would have reached your limit - maybe the site was just acting wonky!
Posts.Title: Confused - How is Metastatic disease diagnosed? del3 DiddleyDoo

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2013 10:14AM DiddleyDoo wrote: Oops - yep, my error.  PET tracers are usually given intraveneously, but are sometimes given orally  - much better than having to drink something.  My BF just had one and he was given an oral solution for his specific concern so that was what was in the front of my mind.  I only addressed the PET scan, since that is what you said you are having tomorrow.  Moreover, it is the best scan for detecting mets for the reason I mentioned above.  I imagine you are quite anxious - the not knowing stage is quite unpleasant (this is where I am), but I hope you can find some comfort in knowing that your doctor has ordered the most sensitive and least invasive detection means we have available and it can look at all of your organs in one scan.  This is a really powerful tool and can detect cancers even before they are visible by MRI or CT, which rely on structural changes - PET detects molecular changes, which will occur before the structural changes.  PET offers a significant advantage over other methods and early detection is key!
Posts.Title: Confused - How is Metastatic disease diagnosed? del3 DiddleyDoo

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2013 11:32AM DiddleyDoo wrote: I agree with Samantha - get the MRI.  It may be a strain/injury to the pectoralis but why not get all the information you can?  You likely won't be comfortable until you know.  As it states, the MRI is more sensitive for detection of occult abnormalities and, should it turn out to be something more concerning, early detection is key for a good prognosis.  I know that I would want any lump, bump or "ya know, this just doesn't look right" completely identified!
Posts.Title: What would you do? Result of Mammo & US Cls1 DiddleyDoo

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2013 07:10AM DiddleyDoo wrote: I think the idea is to concentrate on the area of abnormally. The MRI will take images in about 2-4mm slices depending on the instrument used. It seems a good idea that they would focus the scan to the chest wall. I don't think they will be focused on the lung. One thing is, you will have an opportunity to discuss this with the technician running th scan. They'll want to know where the abnormality is so the can target it.

Posts.Title: What would you do? Result of Mammo & US Cls1 DiddleyDoo

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2013 09:14PM DiddleyDoo wrote: I completely understand. Lumps, bumps, pain and any other abnormalities in the breast are reason for concern and it's scary and frustrating while your here in the waiting room wondering what the heck you might be dealing with. I've read some manuscripts pertaining to MRI for diagnosing IBC and the only thing I've seen directly related to your case is that there can at times be edema at the chest wall, so I think that they should be able to pick it up with what they've ordered. That said, remember this is a rare disease and the chances are in our favor that this isn't what either of us have going on (I have an MRI on Monday to r/o IBC, so I'm right there with ya!). I try to stay positive the best I can, but, admittedly I have my anxieties to deal with, especially as it gets nearer to the time when I should have some answers. When I am able to keep the anxieties at bay, I think about how I'd handle the worse case scenario, simply because if there is cancer then it is already there and I want to have already put some thought into what I would need to do in my personal and professional life. This helps me because it makes me feel a bit more in control. Your silver lining, should you have a dark cloud looming, is that they would be picking up the IBC exceptionally early and that would be a very good thing. Of course, I am certainly hoping for a nice B9 report for you and, again, the odds for that are in your favor. I don't know if this helps. I at least hope I haven't added to your anxieties. This kind of thinking is helpful for me and keeps me sane. I hope the best for you and hope you can enjoy what's left of the weekend. Try to do something fun and relaxing. I'll be thinking of you. Please let us know how everything turns out for you. :)
Posts.Title: What would you do? Result of Mammo & US Cls1 DiddleyDoo

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2013 09:50PM DiddleyDoo wrote: Hi Cls1 - wow, that is a really long scan. I'm sorry you had such a rough day. That would definitely be difficult to endure. Was it at least an open MRI? I can't speak too intelligently about what contrast does but base on the chemical properties do the dye used (iodine or gallidium), it is absorbed by some tissues and enables them tone seen more clearly. I hope you get your results soon. I still haven't heard anything about my test, making me think that it isn't IBC. I wish I knew for certain of course, but I'm thinking that in this case, no news is good news!
Posts.Title: What would you do? Result of Mammo & US Cls1 DiddleyDoo

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2013 07:38AM DiddleyDoo wrote: Hi Cls1 - I'm glad you got these. It does clearly show a bulge at the chest wall.  Do you recall anything that could have caused an injury to your chest muscles?  I'm glad you are doing the additional imaging, as there is obviously something going on here and it is best to identify what it is.  Again, though, the highest probability is that it is something benign, but even with that, I'd want to know what it is, especially if it is giving me discomfort.  Did your doc order the scan with and without gadolinium contrast?  Among other things, the contrast will make inflammation easier to see, which I'm sure they would investigate further, if necessary.  One thing more - have you seen a breast specialist?  This is another option, should you feel uncomfortable with the diagnosis.  The advantage of a breast specialist is that they are looking at breasts all of the time and have seen so many ways disease can present.

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2013 11:28AM DiddleyDoo wrote: Hi. I had non-cancer related thrush a couple of years back. You probably understand that thrush is caused by overgrowth of yeast. I had to use the mouthwash too but found it worked better/faster when I added a daily probiotic and ate more yogurt. I don't know if you're already doing these things but they helped me and might be helpful for you, if you're not.
